Award.AwardTitle: SBE-RCUK: The Effects of Non-peripheralization of Affordable Urban Housing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research supported by this award will enlarge scientific understanding of the social effects of centrally-located affordable urban housing, by testing hypotheses about the impact of housing on economic, political and social life. One recent development to place new housing in centrally-located urban neighborhoods rather than more peripheral ones as often was the case in the past. The new approach encompasses an array of models, including state-planned projects, self-managed state-subsidized cooperatives, state-subsidized rentals, and informal take-overs of repurposed buildings. This research will take advantage of a single city center where all of these approaches are being tried, which provides a natural experiment to investigate a range of social science questions about the relationships between the built environment, social organization, and social mobility. For example, how do differently-modelled affordable housing projects affect employment and economic mobility? How do different projects affect kinshhip, gender relations, and neighborhood sociality? How do they affect civic engagement and urban paricipation?

To answer such questions, an interdisciplinary and international team comprised of anthropologist Dr. John S. Burdick (Syracuse University), geographer Dr. Jeff Garmany (King's College London), anthropologists Dr. Rolf Ribeiro de Souza and Dr. Michelle Lima Domingues (Fluminense Federal University, Brazil), and urban planner Dr. Luciana Correa do Lago (Rio de Janeiro Federal University, Brazil) will undertake research in the downtown port district of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. This site is appropriate for the research because it is home to five clearly distinct models of new affordable housing, all located in close proximity to each other. These include a cooperative administered by a housing organization that practices participatory governance; a cooperative administered by a housing organization that does not practice participatory governance; a building run by the federal housing authority; rent-controlled apartments; and an invader settlement in which families have established an independent organization. The researchers will employ a range of social science methods to collect data: intensive participant observation in the everyday functioning of the different housing projects; in-depth interviews with project residents, repeated at intervals to record change; interviews with urban planners and officials; information sessions with a local expert in urban planning and architecture; and text analysis of housing-related documents and media. Because housing projects and central urban districts are similar throughout the world, answers to these questions will be generalizable and of interest not only to scholars interested in the social effects of housing organization and the built environment, but also to policymakers and urban planners everywhere. The project also will provide training for graduate students and for a postdoctoral scholar. This award is made under the SBE-RCUK Lead Agency Agreement.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to understand how working-class families in Rio de Janeiro engage with different forms of social housing to stay put in the city center, and to see how this affects broader processes of socio-economic wellbeing, kinship and social networks, political mobilization and activism, and contemporary understandings of race and gender. Fieldwork in central Rio de Janeiro began in 2016 and was concluded in 2021.

 

There are at least three key findings that have emerged from this research, all of which contribute to ongoing debates over social housing, urban displacement, diversity in research outputs, and qualitative research methodologies. These findings are described below, highlighting what was learned over the course of the research and providing examples where these findings can be accessed.

 

The first key finding relates to the causes of urban displacement in central Rio de Janeiro, and what factors enable some low-income residents to stay put. While many researchers today argue that gentrification is expanding in cities in the global South, our findings suggest that gentrification alone is insufficient for explaining urban displacement in Southern cities. While gentrification may, indeed, be growing in cities like Rio, there are a host of other factors also at work. This means that working-class families are sometimes pushed out by processes even more brutal than gentrification, but also that informal and illicit economies enable some residents to stay put, in some cases interacting dynamically with changing real estate landscapes. In sum, researchers must account for different factors when considering how urban displacement operates in cities outside of North America and Europe. These findings have already been published in several top outlets, including the journals Antipode, Urban Studies, and City and Society.

 

The second important finding concerns the ways researchers and social activists can work together in mutually reinforcing ways. This is to say that when research participants are consulted on what they would like to see from the project's outcomes and goals, there can be greater reciprocity and 'return' in qualitative research. More significantly, research participants can also learn the tools of social science research to strengthen their work in social activism, indicating that qualitative methodologies like ethnography have the potential to broadly transform social relations. This is best exemplified in a seven-part series of didactic videos called Etnoque? ('Ethno-what?'), produced by our research team to explain ethnographic research and freely available on YouTube.

 

Finally, the third significant finding highlights the value in diverse research outputs, showing how researchers can use open-access technologies to develop products for academic research and teaching, as well as resources open to the general public. For example, in this research, our team developed a YouTube channel where videos documenting the research were archived, helping to create educational content for academic and social activist audiences. In this way, the team helped to develop new outputs that reach a broader audience and add value to academic research and teaching. The YouTube channel is titled Lutas Pela Moradia no Centro da Cidade ('Struggles for Housing in the City Center'), and it is freely available online with English subtitles.

 

Finally, the research team would also like to acknowledge the extraordinary contributions of Professor John Burdick. John led and coordinated this research project until his untimely passing in 2020. He is remembered by his colleagues for his commitments to social justice, activism, and anthropological research, as well as for being a wonderful colleague and friend. A video tribute to John titled 'A Conversation with John Burdick' is openly available on our YouTube channel.
